block.p: >U.S. and Iranian representatives met through secret channels as late as last month despite the controversy over arms sales to free American hostages in Lebanon, House members said George Shultz testified.

Iranian forces captured a town east of the Iraqi city of Basra, Iran claimed. American officials said it was unlikely that the city, which has come under steady artillery fire, would be captured soon.
The U.S. and Japan agreed today that their currencies had recently been buffeted by ''temporary instability'' and that the markets ''warrant monitoring.''

White House officials were dismayed by the election of Jesse Helms as ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Senator Helms's agenda frequently deviates from the Administration's.
Canada demanded that the U.S. make greater efforts to fulfill commitments on trade, acid rain and other issues in a meeting with Vice President Bush in Ottawa.

Signs of the Afghan war persist in a provincial capital. A one-day tour of Jalalabad for foreign reporters was intended to show that a cease-fire was holding. While the reporters saw no fighting, they reported much military activity.
Ecuador will conduct a criminal investigation into the kidnapping of President Leon Febres Cordero, disregarding a promise he made that there would be no reprisals if he was set free.
Diplomats touring Central America and meeting five heads of state failed in efforts to reduce hostilities in the region, some of those involved in the two-day trip said.
Twelve people died in South Africa when gunmen broke into a black home near Durban. The incident was believed part of internecine black strife.
Press-government relations in the Philippines have soured since the beginning of Corazon Acquino's presidency. The Government calls the press mediocre. The press accuses the Government of censorship.
Plans for a Soviet war memorial, on display in Moscow, underwent the scrutiny of Soviet citizens, who usually do not have the chance to comment on the design of public structures.

The Senate passed a Clean Water Act identical to that vetoed by the President last November. The first major bill adopted by the 100th Congress, it will provide $18 billion for sewage treatment facilities.
The 55-mile-an-hour speed limit was retained in a bill approved by the House of Representatives that authorizes $91.6 billion in highway and mass transit funds over the next five years.

A move to overturn Miranda, the 1966 Supreme Court decision, will be supported by the Attorney General, Justice Department officials said. The decision required that the police tell suspects their rights before questioning.

200 people eager for U.S. citizenship waited until midnight outside a Washington post office to take advantage of a first come, first served chance at a visa provided for in the immigration act passed last year.
States are not required to pay women unemployment benefits if their employers refuse to reinstate them after they take time off for pregnancy or childbirth, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously.

A mistrial in Miami was declared by a Federal judge in the case of 7 former members of the city's police department accused of racketeering, possesion of drugs, and involvement in the drowning of three men.
A fugitive wanted by the F.B.I. on charges of trying to blowing up an Air Force R.O.T.C. building in Washington was arrested in Oregon, ending 17 years underground.

Jack F. Kemp was happy to hear that Patrick J. Buchanan would not seek the G.O.P. Presidential nomination. But Mr. Kemp, who will announce his candidacy shortly, admitted he had to ''make the transition from teacher or preacher'' to candidate.
A Bob Dole Presidential organization will soon be set up in Iowa. With the Iowa caucuses more than a year away, Mr. Dole and his rivals are already campaigning hard in the pivotal state.
The trend toward larger homes, with custom kitchens and lavish bathrooms, continues, displays at this year's convention in Dallas of the National Association of Home Builders showed.
Casey had prostate cancer for year
In the House: A lovely fight Regional
No quick L.I.R.R. strike settlement was in sight last night, although negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road made progress with three of 11 striking unions.
S.R.O. hotel residents are harassed and forced out despite a city law intended to preserve the rooms for low-income New Yorkers, tenant lawyers and city officials said.
Greater state tax cuts were demanded by Democrats and Republicans alike, less than 24 hours after Governor Cuomo proposed a $40.9 billion state budget.
6 of top 10 schools in reading on S.I.
